author: metaled

description.text: A hexapod with servo joints. This design is quite big and needs strong servos but looks really cool ^^. I used 20 HD-2213MG Servos (http://www.servodatabase.com/servo/power-hd/hd-2213mg) . If you use other servos you need to modify the embeddings for the servos and servo horns. You may make the upper and lower legs shorter to get shorter leverage. Finally the parts get assembled with M2 thread rod and nuts.

After your modifications you need to mirror the lower and upper legs as well as the servo casing ;) This design is made for ~4.9mm (i used wood) for all parts except the ~1.8mm thick upper leg counterpart (with servo-horn embedding). Cut List:
3 right upper and lower leg parts
3 light upper and lower leg parts
1 upper body part
1 lower body part
3 right servo casings
4 left servo casings
1 head You should lazzzor-cut it in combined mode (raster&vector) to get nice embeddings for the servo-horns and nuts. (The embeddings should be solid filled with a color and have no hairlines) I used M2 hex-head screw (12mm) as back axis for the servos. I have added some photos to see how itâ€™s assembled. You need a lot of nuts and thread rod ;) This is my first upload I hope it works for you. [Robotic Fun]
Daniel

description.text:
This was initially developed for CNC milling but then modified for 3D printing. I have to admit that the milled ones do look much nicer, but without a CNC mill in my home shop they can get expensive. If you know a TIE Pilot looking for some new pieces for his or her armor, this may be of use to you.

I had the original file CNC machined and then made the tapered tooth file, so the photo is the original non-tapered gear.

OT discs, and Fusion 360, and generic red table wine. I have purchased four complete armor kits in order to get one I am happy enough with for 501st approval. These gears, in the aluminum CNC version, along with a real power jack and the knurled knob/ disc will adorn my minimally-demilitarized chest box, in other words kit number five.

The work of a Legion trooper is never done.

description.text:
This is a thin (6mm) Qi Phone Charger rebuilt/redesigned from cheap Qi Chargers you can buy from China - like the one I used this previous project: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1226086

I hate plugging things into my phone. The plug always wears out or gets clogged with pocket crud. My phone has built-in Qi charging capabilities, so I got a cover for the usb port and use wireless charging exclusively.

So I wanted a small, thin Qi charger I could plug into any battery or USB wall plug to take wherever I go. The cheap ones you can buy from China are huge! About the size of a phone. If you open one up, you'll discover is mostly air inside.

So I gutted one and designed a case around the electronics to be as small and thin as possible. This is the result.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

JG Aurora A3 Prusa I3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm & .1mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

You can print the base with/without a raft and on .2mm resolution. I recommend the top be printed at .1mm as it is only .6mm thick. You'll get 4 layers that way (.3mm base + 3 @ .1mm), so it will be more stable and solid.



I printed this in black, but if you print in something more translucent you'll be able to see the charger lights. If you print in clear, you might be able to see all the electronics inside!

Some assembly required...

The top has guides to fit it to the base. Just place all the electronics inside as shown and then glue the top down with Superglue. Now you've got one of the smallest Qi charges anywhere!

Back in 2008 I was playing with robotic gripper designs using RC servos. Several YouTubers have asked for the blueprints so I threw something together in OpenSCAD. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-9pwPNnW5tM The design is based on Vice Grips 4-bar linkage, and was crafted from trial and error rather than CAD and planning :) Here is the youtube description I wrote:
It's a 4-bar linkage design.
  • the longest part (call it part A) is 120mm then a 30 degree bend and 65mm
  • the next longest part B is 100mm then a 45degree bend and 75mm
  • part C mounted to the standard servo is 85mm long and controls the up/down

  • part D is 50mm long and mounts to the micro servo that opens and closes the gripper

  • Part D has a hole 30mm from the center of the microservo horn.
  • There is #6 screw (with washers) that joins part D to part A 10mm from the end of A.
  • There is a #6 screw w/ washers that connects part A at 35mm from the end and 10mm from the end of part B
  • Part C is joined to part B 10mm from the opposite end of the micro servo and 65mm from the end of part B
  • Part E is perpendicular to part C so that the standard servo can raise it up and down.

title: Filament holder for 2020 alu openbeam kossel mini
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I designed a simple filament holder for my Kossel mini, as the spool I use is too small for the original design.

It uses a paper tube from a normal kitchen alu foil pack, and fits all 3 types of filament spools I have at hand.

You will need 2 screws (M3 on my printer) and 2 T-nuts for them to mount the arms.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/dFoDxiEx6xA

I bought the BQ Hephestos last year.
It's my first 3D-printer, and the printer works well. But after approximately 3 months I see potential to optimize it for my needs.

The biggest improvements are the wooden base-plate with handles and the diagonal stiffening. Now I am able to transport the printer without re-calibrating it.

The LCD got a housing including a power switch (power comes from an ATX supply) and a switch for LED-lights. All the power and sensor cables are fix mounted in cable ducts. I only have to connect the power supply cables to a fix mounted terminal.

The Y- and Z-endstops became a new mounting, which allow an easy calbration of the endstops. I also added a energy chain for the Y-table and a heated bead (not connected yet). The heated bead lies on 8mm cork and ontop I placed the glas plate from BQ.

I also added a capacitive sensor at the print head for a future auto-bed-level.

Part-files and real pictures of the printer will come soon. The orientation of the parts for printing might not be correct, but I could print most of the parts without supports.

Update 2016-06-10:
I found a Neopixel Ring with 16 LEDs from Adafruit at home. I bought an Adafruit Trinket 5V and mounted the Neopixel Ring in front of the cooler at the print head. The housing for the Neopixel Ring is at the same time the new mounting place for the capacitive sensor. The Trinket got a housing, which I taped to the back of the Z-frame. I added the printed parts for the housing and the new air nozzle.

Update 2016-06-14:
I added the printed parts for my printbed. I use some plywood instead of the acrylic base from BQ. On top I have 2 layers of 4mm cork as an heat isolator. On top I placed a heated bed MK2 and the glas plate from BQ. In order to support the heated bed in the edges I designed 4 corner pieces. Instead of the paper clamps I printed a side support for the heated bed, which also clamps the glas plate. The heated bed is placed offset in Y-direction about 15mm.

Update 2016-06-16:
I added the printed parts to support the Y-axis-shafts and Z-axis-shafts. With this parts you can also add some diagonal M8-threaded-rods to stiffen the system. A disassembly of the Y-axis-shafts is now easy. Just loosen some nuts and you can take out the hole Y-axis or just the shafts. With the supports of the Z-axis-shafts it is possible to use the old X-axis from BQ. When you put the Z-shafts in the outer holes, you can use e.g. my new X-axis (coming soon). The black blocks under the posts are a EPDM-foam, which act as a kind of vibration-isolator.

Update 2016-06-21:
I uploaded the circuit-diagram how my installation will look like. There are a lot of terminal strips, but I want to have the possibility to use single components later on without de-soldering them. For all hephestos owners, who want to install a heated bed, here is an installation description the BQ support send me: http://www.mibqyyo.com/en-articles/2015/09/25/how-to-install-the-heatbed-on-your-prusa-i3-3d-printer/#/vanilla/discussion/embed/?vanilla_discussion_id=0
The voltage divider and the capacitive sensor for the Z-axis are from http://www.3d-proto.de/index.php?p=tips_autobed#Autobed

title: PrintrBot simple metal Blower fan conversion

description.text:
I have added another shroud design for the Ubis13s

One of the best mods you can do for your PrintrBot is to remove the weak 40mm fan and replace it with a powerful Blower (Centrifugal) fan.

Blower fans are designed to pump air through ducting such as nozzle shroud, something a regular fan really just can’t do.

Cooling the extruded filament quickly will result in much better quality prints especially in areas of prints that are prone to overheating, or features such as bridges or overhangs.

I have designed these parts to easily convert a printerBot simple to use a 50x15mm Blower fan found all over the internet from various suppliers.

There is 2x blower fan adaptors, one of them includes a handy cable guide. If you don’t want or need the cable guide then use the other adaptor.

The Fan shroud includes a built in spacer to compensate for the missing 40mm fan and the nozzle directs air down on to your print with a large opening .

Your original fan bolts and screws are used to fit the new parts and a M4x25mm bolt and nut attaches the Blower fan to the adaptor.

If using the cable guide simply use a cable tie to secure the cable into the guide.

description.text:
Pistolet à élastique en une seule pièce monobloc.
Impression : avec support.
Casser les éventuels points de collage du mécanisme en sortie d’impression et lubrifier, fonctionne mieux avec des élastiques épais. (voir vidéo).

Cela reste un jouet mais les lunettes de protection sont recommandées.

https://youtu.be/SeBTetX97KU

Pistol with elastic(rubber band) in a single room(part,play) monoblock.
Impression(Printing): with support(medium).
To break the possible points of collage(sticking) of the mechanism got out of it from impression(printing) and to grease, works better with thick elastics(rubber bands). (See video).

It remains a toy but the safety glasses are recommended

Le mécanisme du "small rubber gand gun" est moins esthétique mais répond mieux à la fonction, je réaliserai ultérieurement un pistolet de plus grande taille sur ce principe.

The mechanism of " small rubber Ghent gun " is less esthetic but answers better the function(office), I shall realize later a pistol of bigger size on this principle.

Dans un format équivalent, j'ai réalisé celui-ci depuis qui est plus précis au niveau du tir et qui accepte plusieurs tailles d’élastiques.

In a format equivalent, I realized that since it is more accurate in shooting and accepts several sizes of elastic.

title: Honda Insight Fuel Filler Cap Hanger

description.text:
I've been driving this car for a few months now, and I've had to fill it up enough times to be annoyed with the way that the fuel filler door was clearly designed with a way to attach the cap in mind, but the cap itself was not. So I fixed it!  
After printing this I decided to look up how resistant ABS is to gasoline, and... it isn't really? I don't think it should be exposed to enough gasoline vapor to melt it as long as the cap seals properly but I guess we'll see
Print with support. Clip into the groove around the cap

comments.text: PLA is very resistant to organic solvents, try that if ABS does not hold up.

author: petropixel

description.text: Delorean

This is especially designed for the LCD 2x16 screen from http://www.banggood.com/Negative-16-x-2-LCD-Keypad-Kit-RGB-Backlit-For-Raspberry-Pi-p-960166.html and an old Raspberry Pi 1 512 revB.
The final use is to netboot games on a Sega Naomi Arcade Cabinet : http://8bitplus.co.uk/projects/netboot-sega-naomi-netdimm/.

  • case-RasPi_Case2Bottom.stl without hole for SD and leds
  • case-RasPi_Case2Bottom_002.stl with holes for SD and leds
  • case-RasPi_Case2Bottom_003.stl without hole for SD, with holes for Leds

The complete project is using a modified version of piforcetools : https://github.com/ian57/piforcetools

Here is a video https://youtu.be/m5J5HkEwOvA
Delorean Wheel
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/bHsBsO4HtFY

The first and most important thing to calibrate is the exact X/Y displacement and the exact extruder length.

To calibrate the extruder length, a simple test can be performed.

1) Write the actual Esteps/mm value down. You can find the value via menu setting “CONTROL” -> “MOTION” -> "Esteps/mm"

2) disconnect the bowden cable from the hot-end.

3) cut the filament direct behind the Bowden cable

4) perform a feed of 100mm filament (Extruder_1 100mm.gcode)

5) measure the actual length of filament after the bowden cable

6) calculate the new Esteps/mm value

7) set the new Esteps/mm value and store these in the memory!

Formula to calculate the correct Esteps/mm setting:

( Given extrusion length / Actual extrusion length ) * Current Esteps/mm value

For example:
• Measured length after running the gcode file: 95,6 mm
• Current Esteps/mm: 94,2

(100/95,6)*94,2 = 98,54

NOTE:
There are two GCode files. One for a 3D printer with one extruder, or the first extruder of a dual extruder 3D printer;
And a GCode file for the second extruder for a dual extruder 3D printer.

description.text: This is case for the Open Workbench Logic Sniffer as sold by Seeed/Sparkfun/Adafruit etc.

Lengthways the case is 99mm long, so if you are printing this on a Cupcake you will want to make sure that you can print the full 100mm on one axis of your printer. I had to make a couple of changes to mine (change endstops, trim Y-axis pulley) and you will want to make sure the head is centered correctly when the print starts. Also, given the size of the object you will want to make sure you are using a heated build platform otherwise you will no doubt have some issues with warping. Four buttons are included in the design, only two are needed, but given the small size they are likely to have issues, pick the best two to use. The OpenSCAD files are also included.
This was based on the Bus Pirate base I also made.

This is a spacer that is needed to fit a Danalock V2 to a Trioving 5116 lock box.

The idea is to use the provided cross-shaped tail piece to turn the bolt. There is also a small plaque provided, which would hold the tailpiece in place, but this lock box provides no means to attach it. Instead, we stick the plaque to this spacer (use glue or tape, it just needs to stay in place until pressure is applied), and fit the entire spacer into the lock. Then you attach the mounting plate (or adapter plate) using the long M5 screws that come with your lock to hold everything in place.

description.text:
Just a quick design to enclose two Li-ion 18650 batteries. This is loosely designed off the Fat shark goggle battery so it will still fit on the headband and stay in place.

Due to the size of the 18650 cells it's a little larger than the OEM battery (Approx 70 mm x 40 mm x 20 mm)

Please note this has a very tight tolerance as the batteries I used were connected by the aluminium cell tabs and not wires. You may need to increase the size a couple % if you are having difficulty fitting the wires in.

It has thin walls but the design intention was to keep the lid in place with heat shrink (40 mm diameter works ok) which adds a little more solidarity. You could stick/glue it down as you see fit.

If you need design files (SolidWorks) or anything else just let me know.

title: Pegasus Rocket Model
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This Pegasus Rocket model is my first attempt at a large, multi-part model. The tallest part is less than 150 mm tall, so this should work on many types of printers.

8-23-2017:
Removed work-in-progress notice.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Notes:

Pick a low resolution; this model doesn't have a lot of small details and will take a while to print. Structure is only needed on the "Pegasus End" piece.

The "Pegasus Wing" piece has difficulty with delamination on the wingtips, so make sure you have good adhesion if you are going to print full-size. I haven't experienced print failure from the wingtips pulling off the surface, but the wing surface is adversely affected.

Depending on how your material shrinks, you may have to sand or file away excess material to make the parts fit together. Once you can slide them together, glue the pieces in place (superglue works well for ABS and PLA).

title: Working Stargate Mk2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Estimated print time is 112 hours. There are 117 parts.

This stargate model contains additional pieces to move the top chevron as part of the dialling sequence.

Note: The model is slightly larger than the Working Stargate Mk1. Therefore the SGC base on this model will not hold the Mk1 gate firm. Please use the SGC Ramp for Working Stargate Mk1 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1603663

Due to the additional parts for the moving chevron. The space for wires and LED's is much less. I have used surface mount LED's in the model.

Two stepper motors are required for the model. Since the two motors face each other, I have used mounting brackets. If you intend to use a different size motor, you only need to customize the 'stepper_mount_x2.stl' file and not the base.

Besides the Arduino and Adafruit Motor Shield, there is also an optional bracket for an additional circuit board. I have used an additional board to mount the resistors and transistors for the LED's.

The "x" number on the end of the filenames indicate how many times that part should be printed. For instance, "gate_1_a_x8.stl" should be printed eight times.

There is a choice of three types of chevrons.
"chevron_1" is on piece which can be printed as opaque or transparent.
"chevron_2" is three pieces. "a" should be printed opaque and "b" as transparent.
"chevron_3" is three pieces, but is dependant on the print quality. "a" should be printed opaque and "b" as transparent.

In my experience, only the "chevron_4_x9.stl", "rail_l_1_x1.stl" and "rail_r_1_x1.stl" needed to be printed with supports.

Two Arduino scripts are included. "stargate_mk2_full.ino" includes dialling, calibration and light display. "stargate_mk2_dial.ino" includes only dialling and calibration.

Please see the youtube video for a complete assembly guide.
https://youtu.be/6X2FbyxViao

Videos of the Stargate in action

Seven symbol address for Abydos
https://youtu.be/Kvjv6q3YDGc

Eight symbol address for Asgard homeworld.
https://youtu.be/6TiuwvPgPVY

Nine symbol address for Destiny with wrong ninth symbol
https://youtu.be/Wdfw2u-thgw

There are eight videos on my youtube playlist.
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLv5wdS9O16OsT9xOpAUaj0T6JiPvgujXB

Edit 15th Jan 2017
Some of you have contacted me or commented here about problems slicing the parts. Although all the files worked in Makerbot Desktop, they didn't all work in other programs such as Slic3r.

Producing files that worked in both Makerbot Desktop and Slic3r was slightly more challenging than expected. Files fixed in Slic3r didn't all work in Makerbot Desktop or still had errors when re-imported into Slic3r.

An unlikely application came to the rescue. Files fixed in Microsoft's 3D Builder (included in Windows 10) worked in both Makerbot Desktop and Slic3r. I've run all the files through 3D Builder, even the ones without an issue.

If you've had an issue slicing the files then please download the new ones and try again. Comment here or contact me via my website if you have further issues.

Note: The smaller file size is expected as the files are now in binary not ascii format.

Estimated print time assumes standard quality with raft on Makerbot Replicator 5th Generation.

Electronics

By popular demand. Here's my electronics parts list. Please see the reference circuit diagram.

Note : Components can be swapped with equivalents. Also, LED and resistor values will need to be adjusted appropriately.

1 x Arduino
1 x Adafruit Motor/Stepper/Servo Shield for Arduino
2 x Adafruit Stepper motor - NEMA-17 size - 200 steps/rev, 12V 350mA (one stepper could be replaced with a servo).
27 x Kingbright KPT-1608SECK 2.1V 20mA
8 x Broadcom ASMT-YWB1-NGJB2 - 3.2V 60mA
1 x Lumex SLX-LX5093UWC/C - 3.4V 23mA
10 x BC548 NPN transistor
9 x 220 Ohms resistor
8 x 150 Ohms resistor (150R)
1 x 10K Ohms resistor
1 x 10.2 Ohms resistor (10R2)
1 x Photoresistor / light dependent resistor (I used one from the Arduino starter kit)

description.text:
Its a switch for your AA battery pack! Ever found yourself needing to switch on a project? If you are using a AA size battery holder this is the perfect addition. A plastic switch that fits between the terminal of your battery and the holder. Push it one way and the battery touches (ON) and push it the other and it doesn't (OFF). Highly useful. Enjoy.

Inspired by the thought of having to buy and mount a bought switch on an already finished project! Much easier to retrofit a battery box.....

Edit: V 2.2 has been added. Looks very similar to the original but it may work in places the original does not.

Edit: 17-7-2016

description.text:
I've been looking for a nice way to store my Rubik's and twisty puzzle collection but getting those simple pyramid type stands for like 20 puzzles can get quite expensive and is boring right?
So here comes 3D printing to help once again, after thinking about some ways I could store them and playing with some designs I came up with this minimalistic cube stand that can hold 3 puzzles of any kind,shape, weight and size.

The basic ''tri tower'' file provided will securely store 3 cubic puzzles off a wide variety (my biggest cube is a shengshou 5x5x5 and still has some room for bigger puzzles).
I also made a few adaptations to the files for the stand to hold special puzzles with odd angles in the top slot, currently I am having versions for a pyraminx, megaminx and 4x4 octahedron. These files also have the angle of the top slot in the name in case you have puzzles with similar angles.

I hope some of you big collectors out there find some use in this and if you like it be sure to print one (or more) out and share your makes, I would also love it if you could share the thing with your friends if you think your friend's collection is a mess and needs some organizing ;).

P.S.: If there is enough request I should be able to adjust the top slot for ''any'' type of puzzle pretty easy I think (provided I can find the angle I need).

title: Fusebox 3 point bed leveling adapter(now with LOGO!)

description.text:
I created an adapter so that I could use 3 point bed leveling on a Fusebox. Screws onto the bed frame right at the end of the extrusions, but use the third hole on your heated bed to line it up perfectly.

Note: This may not quite fit your setup. Here is the link to TinkerCAD if you need to edit it: https://tinkercad.com/things/5SHOg6t36YY
All you should need to do is to make sure the length works, and the center hole lines up with your bed.

Recommend printing in ABS/PETG/HTPLA as this piece will be exposed to the heat from the heated bed.

06/09/2016 - Updated the stl to raise the middle section so a much longer screw isn't needed. Oriented so supports won't be required.

06/16/2016 - Updated the stl because the raised middle section was bending under the pressure of the spring. Thickened that up, beefed up support for the the screw holes, added FuseBox logo.

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I used standard Fusebox print settings, but with 3 perimeters the infill only applies to the middle section the spring pressure is applied to, so make sure it's enough to prevent bending.

This is a new design for a spool holder over a t-slot. Materials:

  • 1 x Spool holder cube
  • 3 x 5mm screw
  • 2 x t-slot stoppers
  • 1 x 5mm nut
  • 1 x 8mm screw rod
  • 2 x rod stoppers pieces (palometas)
  • 2 x 8mm nuts for the rod stops

Mount cube on the t-slot by means of the t-slot stoppers and two 5 mm screws. Then insert the 8mm screw rod in the cube and fix it with an other 5 mm screw (remember to insert the corresponding nut before in the cube). You can install you plastic spool using the corresponding adapter and finally you can mantain it in place using the rod stoppers (each using a 8mm nut). Two rod stoppers are needed to avoid the spool to "walk out" of the rod, for this purpose both rod stoppers should be tight together.

title: Adjustable Bed Clamps, now in OpenSCAD.

description.text:
These print bed clamps are adjustable without removing the glass. The side clamps have a recessed area to keep the print bed from slipping up and the wedge adjuster is in line with the y motion to avoid any collisions on the sides. The screws are 20 mm M3s.
I do the bed leveling with a digital indicator mounted on the extruder carriage and the side clamps finger tight. Once it's level, I tighten the side clamps.
The clamps are printed in ABS, .20 layers, .4mm nozzle, 220C nozzle, 110C bed.

This simple trap grab the mole alive so do not worry about it.

Print: all the parts must be align on the flat surface except the frame.
I aligned the frame on the outside. that need just a few support while printing.

  • Screw 2 pieces of M5 nuts on the doors. This weights keep the door in closed position,
  • Put 2x 3mm diameters x 28mm long of shaft in the frame to hold the door,
  • insert the two assembled frames each end of the pipe glue it if needed. make sure the doors be parallel.
  • When you use the hinge must be on top. The doors must be open and close easy.

Do not kill animals!

title: Motorcycle license plate LED light brackets

description.text:
Used to mount LED lights such as the Skene P3 or other strip lights, but could also be used to mount reflectors or reflective tape (or whatever else I suppose).

There are two versions of the bracket here- the one with "retrofit" in the title is there in the case that someone didn't want to cut/rewire their existing lights and allows running the cable through the slot in the side instead of the back. New installations can use the hole through the bottom, and not have the slots in the inner edges that serve no other purpose.

The photo is from an older design, but close enough. This design fits the Skene P3 lights better, without as much empty space above and below the light strip, as well as other iterative changes/improvements.

description.text:
I have failed to find the perfect bearing for my needs so I decided to make my own. This is what I can up with. It uses 8 cylinders instead of balls to increase printing results. Scale this object and edit it to fit your needs!

You can download or use the program Autodesk123D Design to add your own shaft hole (that sounded weird :|). Just snap your shaft onto the face of the inner circle, lower the shaft into the model, and subtract the shaft from the bearing. There you go, you own customized bearing for all of your bearing needs!

Warning: I have not printed or tested out this model so it is on you if you decide to print it. I will update the description when I have fixed my printer and have printed this model.

description.text:
DM: As you stealthily look around the corner you see the interior of the room. It appears to be a barracks occupied by 25-30 well armed hobgoblins. Some are playing cards, some are eating, a few are sparring with swords, and more are laying in their bunks.

Player: I put on my hat of disguise, and take the form of the hobgoblin guard we killed earlier. Then I walk into the barracks to gather information.

DM: As you walk among the hobgoblins, none of them give you a second look. As you near the back of the room you hear a raspy breathing sound. Make a perception roll.

Player: 14

DM: smiling as you turn toward the breathing you see an odd white and green creature with four hands as it disappears into nothingness. Even stranger it seems to be holding in one of it's hands a hat of disguise identical to your own. Only after you feel the eyes of 30 hobgoblins upon you do you realize that it was your hat.

Any resemblance between this model and John Kasich is purely coincidental.

title: Dealgan inspired spindle
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is an 3D model is designed after and inspired by an old Scottish spindle called dealgan, farsadh or fairsaid.

You can read more about the interesting dealgan spindle here: Spin like you're Scottish - plying on the whorl-less spindle

To learn how to spin or ply on one of these spindles watch these three videos :)

  • Spin like you're Scottish
  • Ply like you're Scottish
  • Plying on the Tardis

If you are interested in spinning with spindles I also recommend checking out the group Spindlers on Ravelry :)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Notes:

To get a big spindle like the pink one in the pictures enlarge the model by 160%.

If your printer has good cooling however you can print a mini spindle like the white one, by printing the model at standard size.

After a lot of experimentation it seems like this spindle will print at any size and with any settings that you would like.

Experiment with size and infill and print a spindle that is perfect for you :)

comments.author: chivampir

comments.text: In my own designs of one of these spindles I hollowed out the inside by "subtracting" material and leaving a "plug" in the bottom.  My idea was to move the majority of the mass to the outside of the spindle and lower the center of gravity.  The center of gravity can be moved by using a much higher fill ratio which leaves the walls of the spindle and stem almost solid (especially if you use 4 shells) and the plug much heavier.  It is interesting to note that hollowing out the inside increases the overall weight of the spindle.

The abacus is the most ancient calculating device known. It has endured over time and is still in use in some countries. An abacus consists of a wooden frame, rods, and beads. Each rod represents a different place value—ones, tens, hundreds, thousands, and so on. Each bead represents a number, usually 1 or 5, and can be moved along the rods. Addition and subtraction can easily be performed by moving beads along the wires of the abacus.

This particular model is a chinese abacus.

NOTE: The size of the beads is a little smaller in the stl file as compared to the photos, as the original size did not leave enough empty space on the shaft.

Make the basic shape of the abacus extrude it to desired thickness draw and extrude a circle to make a shaft on which beads can slide on draw and extrude a circle to make basic shape of bead (offset extrude) Extrude another circular shaft which can act as suppoert while printing, this can be easily broken after printing is complete. Add fillet Use linear pattern to make beads use linear pattern to make beads and 13 shafts with equal spacing.

Abacus: Tool to sharpen your brain

One of the advantages of abacus study is that learners can calculate simple mathematical problems rapidly and accurately. In addition, they acquire the ability of do mental calculation utilizing the abacus image, which allows quick calculation without actually using the abacus.
This makes it an excellent tool, especially for children of young age to sharpen their brains.

How to use an abacus

This model is a chinese abacus, it has more calculative ability than other types of abacus.
The internet is overflowing with the information on this topic, and youtube videos are a better way to understand the method to use an abacus. But for a general understanding here is a link to a great website that teaches how to use a chinese abacus:
http://mathforum.org/library/drmath/view/65236.html

author: ichibey

description.text:
The Gen 6 electronics included with the Orca V0.3 only allow 1/8 steps (loud) don't have any way to monitor or control bed temp, and require 2 power supplies, one for the bed and one for everything else. So I've deiced to upgrade the Orca V0.3 to Ramps electronics. 
Now I don't have to worry about leaving the printer running when I leave the house. The heated bed will shut down as soon as the print is finished.

The easiest way to mount the ramps board was to use a peace of 1/4 inch plywood with the traced out shape of the Gen 6 Electronics then drill holes that fit the ramps electronics. 
I was surprised to find out that the Motor connectors on the Orca V0.3 fit ramps electronics, all you need to do is use a pair of side cutters to remove the two tabs. 
You'll need to come up with an adapter for the thermistor attached to the hot end and solider a few wires to supply power to the heater resistor. I used 2 peaces of 1/4 inch plywood under the heated bed to give me room for wiring. 
I also used a 12v 30amp power supply to power everything. Seems to keep up with ABS printing with out much problem. The reprap heated bed I'm using reduces the printing height by about 6mm but that doesn't really cause me to much of a problem. 
The zip file attached has the Sprinter file with adjusted settings that I've been using to run the Ramps board with the Orca 0.3 frame. Hopefully that will give you a good start if you decide to make the upgrade. 
The end stops included with the Orca 0.3 don't really work with ramps electronics so you'll need to pick up some micro switches or optos if you want end stops. Overall I think the upgrade is a Great improvement to a very solid base, It would be nice if the Orca 0.3 shipped with proper electronics to begin with. 
Anyone want to buy a Gen 6 board with power supply?

title: Motor mounts for Gold Spark Gearmotors (pair)

description.text:
Please note that there is a bit of extra space on the bottom half of the mount. Place a piece of sticky two-sided foam tape here to keep the motor in place, as well as provide a little cushioning to absorb sharp jolts to the system. In addition, the holes will need to be drilled to a custom diameter (I used 4-40 screws). A useful tip is to drill a hole slightly smaller than the diameter of your desired screws. This will allow the screws to create a threading in the plastic eliminating the need for nuts.   
The skb file can be modified in google sketchup and exported as an stl if you would like to make modifications.  
Check out my website: teamctrlaltdelete.weebly.com
